sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Functional rubber nanocomposites with practical and charming characteristics such as flexibility, improved mechanical properties, being recycled and shape memory effect are promising for sustainable applications in soft robotics, smart medical devices, and intelligent response switches. The common strategy for designing commercial rubbers to achieve high mechanical performances basically depends on two aspects: a developed crosslink network1-3 and/or effective fillerreinforcing system.4-6 Unfortunately, owing to the irreversible chemical networks yielding from sulfur vulcanization and peroxide curing, the current industrial crosslinking techniques, rubbers are more likely to be turned into thermosets with impossibility of recycling.7,8 Although devulcanization, a technique combining thermal and mechanical treatment, can recycle some crosslinked rubbers, the chain scission inevitably lowers the performance of recycled rubbers.9,10 Introducing reversible covalent bonds1,11,12 into rubber’s network can make rubber self-healed, reshaped and recycled and simultaneously keep their mechanical properties at relatively high level. However, in most cases, commercial rubbers must be treated by complex chemical modifications in order to equip with the desirable functional groups,13-15 which severely limits the practical application of this method. Compared with reversible covalent bonds, physical crosslinks are easily produced in rubbers and have been reported in many documents regarding self-healing and derived recycling.16,17 Nevertheless, rubbers have to suffer from inferior mechanical performances without covalent crosslinks. Incorporation of effective nanofillers has been manifested to be the most conducive approach to overcome this problem. It was reported that the dispersion of nanofillers and the interfacial interactions between rubber matrix and nanofillers are critical to the mechanical properties of the nanocomposites. Those effective nanoparticles, e.g. carbon nanotubes (CNT),18,19 graphene,20,21 cellulose nanocrystals22,23 and nanoclays,24,25 can easily develop strong physical interactions with rubber chains, serving as multiple-functional netpoints. However, nanoparticles are well dispersed in rubber and closely surrounded by rubber matrix preventing the removal of them during rubber’s recycling. The retained nanofillers severely restrict the further applications of regenerated rubbers. Thus, it is a challenge for sustainable development of rubber nanocomposites to recycle the rubber matrix without any retained pristine nanofillers and molecular degradation. To confront this challenge, we selected carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCS), a water-soluble derivative of chitosan, as the filler and fabricated a novel carboxylated styrene-butadiene rubber (XSBR)/CMCS film with considerable mechanical properties. Because CMCS can be dissolved and removed by water, the rubber matrix of XSBR/CMCS film can be recycled. Our rubber films are crosslinked by a special CMCS nano-capillary network without any irreversible chemical bonds. Surprisingly, the film owns appropriate shape memory effect in a suitable temperature range for human body (10~15°C) due to its rigid CMCS framing network, which can be used as a band-aid for emergent bone fracture. In addition, our method to fabricate this rubber film is eco-friendly and does not pose any hazards and threats to the environment.

3 latex with a solid content 50 wt% was purchased from Wuhan Fengyaotonghui chemical products Co., Ltd. (China). The XSBR is a random copolymer which consists of 62 wt% styrene, 35 wt% butadiene and 3 wt% carboxyl functional monomer. 2.2 Materials Preparation: 4 wt % CMCS solution was firstly obtained by completely dissolving CMCS powder in deionized water under a stirring rate held at 1000 r/min at room temperature. Then, the CMCS solution was dropped slowly into the XSBR latex using an injector under vigorous stirring (2000 r/min). After stirring 20min continuously, the XSBR/CMCS mixture was degassed in ultrasound for 60 minutes to remove the air bubbles. Followed, the XSBR/CMCS mixture was concentrated at 40°C under continuous mild stirring (500 r/min) to be a stable thicker homogeneous emulsion. Then the thicker solution was poured into a mirror-polished glass mould covered with anti-adherent film and vacuum dried at 40 ℃ until constant weight. The CMCS content in the dried XSBR/CMCS films was tailored at 5, 10, 15, 20, 25 and 30 wt% by changing the amount ratio of CMCS solution and XSBR latex. 2.3 Materials Characterization: XPS data were obtained with an ESCALAB MKII XPS instrument by using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. A pass energy of 50 eV and a spot size of 500 μm was used, energy step size was 1.000 eV. FTIR spectra was taken from 4000~700cm-1 with a resolution of 4 cm-1 and 64 scans, by using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nexus470, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA), attenuated total reflectance (ATR) model for the films. DSC analysis was performed on a METTLER DSC 3 (METTLER TOLEDO, Swiss). The test samples were sealed in aluminum pans and scanned from -80 to 100 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min under a N2 atmosphere. TEM observation was carried out by using a JEM-2100F with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV in high vacuum mode. The test samples were ultramicrotomed into thin sections with about 100 nm in thickness using a ultramicrotome Leica EMUC6 at -100 °C (liquid nitrogen atmosphere). SEM observation was performed in a Merlin SEM (Zeiss, Germany) with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV in high vacuum mode, spray-gold for the test samples. XRD profiles were obtained by using X-ray diffractometer (DX-2700A, Dandong China) at the voltage of 40 kV and the current of 40mA. The scanning angle was from 5o to 70o, step length 0.02. Particles size was determined by a laser scattering particle size analyzer (NanoBrook Omni, Brookhaven). DMA was conducted on a METTLER DMA 1 (METTLER TOLEDO, Swiss) in tension mode, rectangular sample with 8mm×4mm×0.5mm, heating rate 3°C/min, temperature ranging from -50 to 150 °C, frequency 1Hz. 2.4 Equilibrium swelling experiment: The weighed specimens were immersed in toluene for 72h at room temperature and then vacuum dried at 60°C until constant weight. Shape fixity ratio (SF) and shape recovery ratio (SR) were calculated according to the equation (4)29. Five specimens were measured for each sample and the calculated results were the average values. Figure 1. Preparation and structural characterization of the XSBR/CMCS films. a) schematic illustration showing preparation of XSBR/CMCS films via concentrating the mixture of XSBR/CMCS solution. b) Appearance of the XSBR/CMCS films. c) TEM images showing the evolution of structural morphologies of regenerated CMCS in films.
The chemical structures of CMCS and XSBR are shown in Figure S1 and S2 (Supporting Information), respectively. Our rubber films were prepared by concentrating the mixture of XSBR latex and CMCS solution at a mild temperature—40°C (Figure 1a) under continuous stirring. During this process, the viscosity of mixture increased incessantly due to water evaporation, simultaneously, the stirring helped to avoid the agglomeration and precipitation of CMCS. We controlled the viscosity of mixture until it became a stable homogeneous emulsion and then poured the solution into a mirror-polished glass mould covered with anti-adherent film. Since most of CMCS molecules were unfolded in solution, more hydrophilic groups, e.g. carboxyl, amino and hydroxyl groups, were exposed to XSBR. The chains of CMCS and XSBR frequently and thoroughly contacted, entangled and interacted through hydrogen bonding to form large amounts of physical crosslinks.30,31 After dried in vacuum at 40 ℃ to a constant weight, a series of films containing different contents of CMCS were prepared. The transparency of films reduced gradually with the increasing content of CMCS. When the CMCS content reached 15 wt%, the film was basically opaque (Figure 1b). The CMCS was found regenerated in the XSBR matrix, thus we investigated the evolution of their structural morphologies by TEM (Figure 1c). The TEM image of neat XSBR is provided in Figure S3a, (Supporting Information), which shows no fibrous and granular substances in the neat XSBR. However, at low content of 5 wt%, there are many nanoparticles exhibiting several to over ten nanometers, dispersing homogeneously in the XSBR, which should be the regenerated CMCS. With the increasing content of CMCS, the regenerated CMCS changed its morphology from typical nanoparticles to nano-fibril. In fact, there are some evidences of the particle-fibril transition in the TEM image of the film with 10wt% CMCS (Fig. 1c). We also provide other TEM images of the film with 5 wt% and 10wt% CMCS in the Figure S3b and S3c (Supporting Information),

The regenerated CMCS aggregated as nanoparticles at low CMCS content can be further confirmed by SEM observation (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Compared with the neat XSBR (Figure S4a), the appearance of nanoparticles in Figure S4b and Figure S4c should be the regenerated CMCS. When the content exceeded 15 wt%, a well-developed nano capillary-like network was constructed by regenerated CMCS nano-fibers (Figure 1c). Because the regeneration of CMCS and entangling/interaction between XSBR and CMCS chains via hydrogen bonding were in situ formed synchronously,17,32 the massive agglomeration of CMCS was efficiently inhibited. In addition, the orderly arrangement of chains in regenerated CMCS was also disorganized (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

The formation of hydrogen bonding between regenerated CMCS and XSBR is confirmed by the combined analysis of XPS and FTIR. Because the binding energy of a core level electron depends on its chemical environment within the molecule, the binding energy provides useful information for the specific interactions between polymers at the surfaces33. 7 main elements: carbon, nitrogen and oxygen, with binding energy at around 280 eV, 400 eV and 530 eV, respectively, while XSBR mainly contained carbon and oxygen (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The CMCS shows three carbon signals in high-resolution C1s spectra at 284.4 eV (CN), 285.6 eV (C=O) and 287.4 eV (C-O),34,35 and the XSBR shows its binding energy of C1s for C=O and C-O at 285.0 eV and 287.4 eV, respectively. In our films, the binding energies of C=C and C-C had no changes at 283.8 eV, while the binding energy of C=O was shifted to 284.8 eV, which was 0.2 eV and 0.8 eV lower than that of XSBR and CMCS, respectively (Figure 2a). This demonstrated that the C=O of XSBR and CMCS participated in the formation of hydrogen bonding. Similarly, the N1s peak of XSBR/CMCS film was shifted from 398 eV of CMCS to 399 eV (Figure S7, Supporting Information), confirming that the -NH2 of CMCS was also involved in hydrogen bonding. As for the FTIR spectrum in Figure 2b, the absorptions at 3411 cm-1 and 1425 cm-1 in the spectrum of CMCS are ascribed to the peaks of hydroxyl and amide Ⅱ, respectively. The XSBR shows a broad absorption at 3500~3200 cm-1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of O-H (the maximum peak at 3417 cm-1).31,36 As expected, as the CMCS content increases from 0 to 30 wt%, the hydroxyl peak and amide Ⅱ peaks of XSBR/CMCS films are shifted from 3417 to 3375 cm-1 and 1425 to 1403 cm-1,37,38 respectively, substantiating that hydrogen bonding was formed between carboxyl, amino and hydroxyl groups of XSBR and CMCS (Figure 2c). Therefore, the CMCS capillary network, taking their relative rigid molecular structure into consideration, served as the supporting framework to make XSBR molecules crosslinked via hydrogen bonding, fabricating a “reinforced concrete structure” (Figure 2c 2d and 2e). To address this, we prepared a series of contrast samples through directly adding CMCS particles into XSBR and determined their crosslink densities through a well-known equilibrium swelling experiment.39,40 The CMCS used in our experiment are white powder (Figure S8, Supporting Information) with an average size of 810 nm (Figure S9, Supporting Information). Since most of hydrophilic groups were shielded inside the particles, hydrogen bonding was only formed on the surface of CMCS particles.5,17,41 As shown in Figure S10 (Supporting Information), the n of references is increased from 1.35×10-4 mol/cm-3 to 3.32×10-4 mol/cm-3 with the CMCS content increasing from 5 wt% to 30 wt%. However, compared with the CMCS particles, the CMCS nano-capillary network provided more reactive sites for bridging with XSBR molecules via hydrogen bonding in our XSBR/CMCS films. As seen, the n increases from 1.55×10-4 mol/cm-3 for 5 wt% CMCS to 4.72×10-4 mol/cm-3 for 30 wt% CMCS. Consequently, the CMCS nano-capillary network propped the XSBR molecules to form a denser and stronger network structure (Figure 2e). It ought to be accentuated that this special “reinforced concrete structure” could effectively improve the mechanical properties of the XSBR/CMCS films. For example, the tensile strength of XSBR is increased from 2.75MPa to 9.57 MPa with incorporation of 30 wt % CMCS, nearly 3.5 times that of the neat XSBR. However, the tensile behavior of the films gradually changed toward rigid plastics with the continuously completed CMCS nano-capillary network (Figure 3a). Particularly, such a rigid CMCS network could be preliminarily formed when the CMCS content was beyond 10 wt%. As seen in Figure 3b, the Young’s modulus of film, representing the stiffness of materials, only increased from 1.51 MPa to 3.62 MPa with incorporation of 10 wt% CMCS. When the CMCS was 15 wt%, the Young’s modulus of film sharply increased to 8.65MPa, almost 5.7 times that of the neat XSBR. This is in agreement with the morphology evolution of CMCS observed in Figure 1c. As the content of CMCS further increases to 30 wt%, the well-developed rigid CMCS capillary network functions as framework to stiffen the films via hydrogen bonding,

Reinforcing effect of rigid CMCS capillary network on the mechanical properties of XSBR/CMCS films. a) Typical tress-strain curves. b) Young’s modulus. c) Stress-strain cycles of XSBR/CMCS films during successive tensile tests. d) Fracture energy. e) SEM images of the tensile fracture surface of XSBR/CMCS film with 20 wt% CMCS.
To further explore the functions of this magical CMCS nano-capillary network on the performance of films, we conducted successive stretching for the films and showed their hysteresis loops in Figure 3c. The detail residual strains for every cycle are provided in Table S1 (Supporting Information). It is noteworthy that the residual strain of the film with 5 wt% CMCS is lower than that of neat XSBR. For example, the residual strain of XSBR in the 3rd cycle (=150%) is 40%, while that of the film with 5 wt% CMCS is only 13%. This is attributed to the different morphology structure of regenerated CMCS in the XSBR. In the film with 5 wt% CMCS, the regenerated CMCS aggregated as nanoparticles dispersed uniformly in the XSBR matrix (Figure 1c), which could improve the elastic recovery of the XSBR by acting as physical multiple-functional netpoints.36,42 However, differing to the particles, the rigid CMCS capillary network had more reactive sites for bridging with XSBR molecules, which reduced the extensibility and retained a high residual strain for the films. For example, the residual strain of XSBR in the 1st cycle (=50%) was 11%, while that of the film with 25 wt% CMCS was increased to 30%. As for the film with 30 wt% CMCS, its

As a result, when the CMCS content exceeded 10 wt%, the reduced elongation at break played a dominating role in reducing the fracture energy value which was calculated from integration of the stress-strain curve17 (Figure 3d). To get a better understanding of the framing effect of rigid CMCS capillary network, we also provide the typical stress-strain curve of reference sample (20 wt% CMCS) in Figure S11 (Supporting Information). The reference sample has a typical soft rubbery characteristic with higher elongation but lower stress compared with the one owning rigid CMCS capillary network. As seen, the stress strength and elongation of our film are 9.6 MPa and 280%, respectively, while that are 3.6 MPa and 580% for the reference sample. This remarkable difference strongly confirmed that the rigid CMCS capillary network in our XSBR/CMCS films was distinct from that in the reference sample. The SEM images of the tensile fracture surface of XSBR/CMCS film are shown in Figure 3e. The neat XSBR exhibited a smooth fracture surface (Figure S12, Supporting Information) while the XSBR/CMCS film manifested a much rough fracture surface with conspicuous brittle fracture of the inside CMCS capillary network. The observed CMCS network morphology is quite consistent with the TEM observation. The powerful interactions between XSBR and rigid CMCS nano-capillary network effectively transferred load from the XSBR matrix to the CMCS network, which endowed the film with larger bearing capacity before fracture.

After soaked in the deionized water for 120 hours at 40℃, the mass loss of the film with 5 wt% CMCS was 5.5%, suggesting that the CMCS was removed completely at this time. In this case, the film could keep its integrity of shape and only swell in the water (Figure 4b). Obviously, the more developed network of CMCS is, it is easier for the water to transfer along network channels into the inside of films as well. Therefore, at the first 6 hours’ water bath, the mass loss of the film with 15 wt% CMCS was as high as 11% and it further increased to 27% for the film with 30wt% CMCS. Soaked in the deionized water for 24 hours, the mass loss of the film with 30 wt% CMCS was up to ~30 wt%, indicating that almost all the CMCS had been removed at this time (Figure 4a). Then, without the CMCS capillary network and its hydrogen-bond crosslinking system, the residual XSBR was dispersedly precipitated in the water (Figure 4c). The high similarity of FTIR spectrum (Figure 4d) and no mechanical performance losing (Figure 4e) confirmed the recycling of XSBR without residual CMCS. Furthermore, the peak of binding energy at around 400 eV which belonged to nitrogen disappeared in the XPS spectrums of recycled XSBR (Figure S13, Supporting Information). All these experimental results confirmed that the CMCS was removed completely. The typical recycled XSBR film prepared through a series of vacuum drying, mill masticating and mould pressing is shown in Figure 4f.

The maximum of the tan δ curve showed that XSBR owned a suitable glass transition temperature (Tg) (16.6 °C) near room temperature (Figure S14, Supporting Information). The thermal transitions of films were also studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) thermograms (Figure S15, Supporting Information). The Tg determined by DSC is around 1 °C which is ~15 °C lower than that determined by DMA. However, the Tg of film determined by DSC slightly increased from 1.1 to 1.4 °C with incorporation of 30 wt% CMCS. This significant differences of Tg is originated from the different mechanism for testing Tg through two kinds of methods. The DSC measures the enthalpy changes of materials while the DMA highly relies on the test frequency45. Nevertheless, both DMA and DSC confirmed that the Tg of XSBR was above 0 °C, which endowed the XSBR/CMCS films with potential shape memory effect near room temperature. As expected, the developed rigid CMCS nano-capillary network could significantly promote the shape fixing ratio (SF) (Figure 5b). For instance, at 10 °C, an acceptable external temperature of human body, the SF of XSBR was only 69%, while it increased to 100% with developed rigid CMCS nano-capillary network (CMCS content was beyond 15 wt%). Although the rigid CMCS capillary network reduced the extensibility and elasticity recovery of the films, the shape recovery ratio (SR) of all the films were over 90% when the triggering temperature was above 40 °C, showing considerable shape fixity and shape recovery capability (Figure 5b). In addition, we found that the rigid CMCS nano-capillary network, serving as supporting frame, could increase the maximum temperature for 100% fixing the films (Figure 5c). For example, the SF of the film with 5 wt% CMCS was 80% at 10 °C. To get a perfect 100% SF for it, the maximum temperature had to decrease to about 8°C. However, the maximum temperature for 100% SF in spiral shape can be increased to 11 and 13.8 °C for the film with 15 and 30 wt% CMCS (Movie S1, Supporting Information), respectively, that the temperature was more comfortable to human body. The shape memory behavior of the XSBR/CMCS films were also qualitatively demonstrated by shape recovery sequence of rectangular strip46 (Movie S2 and S3, Supporting Information) and “V” shaped films47,48. The “V” shaped film with 20 wt% CMCS only needs 13s to get a 92% shape recovery at 40 °C (Figure 5d). This suggested that shape-fixed film could rapidly regain its flexibility characteristics when contacting with human body (body temperature is ~37 °C). Recently, Huang et.al49,50 reported a series of rubber-like shape memory polymers based on silicone which can be programmed at body temperature. Those materials are not only soft and flexible (with lower tensile strength at about 0~2MPa), but also have excellent repeatable thermal-assisted healing function, thus they are quite suitable for comfort fitting. However, as for our XSBR/CMCS film, it owned higher mechanical properties due to the existence of the rigid CMCS nano-capillary network. Taking the film with 30 wt% CMCS for example, it is a rigid film with modulus of 465 MPa at 10°C where 100% shape fixing was obtained, while it is a typical elastomer at 37 °C with modulus of several tens MPa. The stress-strain curves of the film programmed at 10 °C and 37 °C are shown in Figure S16 (Supporting Information). This shape memory behavior in such a coincidental temperature range is quite suitable for designing a smart medical device for human body, e.g. bandaid for emergent bone fracture (Figure 5e and f). When the ambient temperature is below 14 °C, the top lateral side of the film plays a role in fixing the band shape to fix the bone and the inside layer wall-attached skin recovers to be flexible rubber buffer to protect the fracture part, lessening secondary injury and saving manpower as well. However, the SF of materials are affected by the programming strain and deformation rate since the consequent creeping/relaxation behavior of polymer could reduce the SF51. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, herein, we report a kind of original XSBR/CMCS films with considerable mechanical properties, recycling and appropriate shape memory effect. The films were prepared by concentrating the mixture of XSBR latex and CMCS solution under continuous stirring. The unfolded CMCS molecules in solution exposed more hydrophilic groups to XSBR during concentration, meanwhile, CMCS nano-fibrils were regenerated and entangled with XSBR chains, which constructed a mutualism physical crosslink network via hydrogen bonding. When the CMCS content exceeded 10 wt%, we observed that a rigid CMCS nano-capillary network was formed in the XSBR. This “reinforced concrete structure” effectively improved the mechanical properties of the XSBR/CMCS films. When the CMCS content was 30 wt%, the tensile strength and Young’s modulus of film were increased to 9.57MPa and 14.10MPa, nearly 3.5 and 9.3 times that of the neat XSBR, respectively. However, the framing effect of rigid CMCS capillary network reduced the extensibility of films. On the other hand, the water-soluble CMCS capillary network running through the whole film could be removed completely by water. This turned out a sustainable recycling for the rubber without any retained pristine fillers, as well as molecular degradation. Importantly, the recycled XSBR showed no mechanical performance loss. Lastly, our XSBR/CMCS films exhibited superior shape memory behavior in a coincidental temperature range, which is quite suitable for designing a smart medical device for human body, e.g. band-aid for emergent bone fracture. The films (CMCS content beyond 15 wt%) could get a 100% shape fixing at 11~ 14 °C and over 90% shape recovery at 40 °C. That is to say, the top lateral side of the film fixed the band shape at an ambient temperature below 14 °C while the inside layer wall-attached skin (~37°C) could recover to be flexible rubber buffer to protect the fracture part. Taken together, the XSBR/CMCS films we fabricated with rigid CMCS nano-capillary network integrated with improved mechanical properties, recycling and appropriate shape memory effect at body temperature have great promising and sustainable applications in soft robotics, smart medical devices, and intelligent response switches.

metadata.abstractText: The universal strategy for designing commodity rubbers to obtain high mechanical performances mainly relies on two aspects: either a developed crosslink network or an effective filler-reinforcing system. However, recycling of rubbers cannot bypass them. In this paper, strengthened and recyclable shape memory carboxylated styrene-butadiene rubber (XSBR)/carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCS) films are prepared by concentrating the mixture of XSBR latex and CMCS solution. During this process, the CMCS were regenerated due to water evaporation and synchronously entangled with XSBR chains, which constructed a mutually physical crosslink network via hydrogen bonding. With the increasing content of CMCS, regenerated CMCS changed its morphology from typical nanoparticles to nano-fibrils. When the CMCS content exceeded 10 wt%, a rigid CMCS nano-capillary network was formed in the films, constructing a special “reinforced concrete structure”. This rigid CMCS nano-capillary network significantly improve the mechanical properties of the XSBR/CMCS films. At the same time, due to the capillary network running through the whole film, the XSBR could be recycled by soaking films in water without any retained CMCS. Furthermore, our XSBR/CMCS films exhibited impressive shape memory behavior in a coincidental temperature range which is quite suitable for designing a smart medical device for human body, e.g. band-aid for emergent bone fracture.
